definition:
Let $X$ be a topological space and $R$ be a commutative ring. The
diagonal map $\Delta: X \to X \times X$ induces a chain map between
singular cochain complexes:
$$\Delta^*: C^*(X \times X;\, R) \to C^*(X; \, R)$$.

Let $h:C^*(X ;\, R) \otimes C^*(X ;\, R) \to C^*(X \times X;\, R )$

denote the chain homotopy equivalence associated with the Kunneth .

Given $\alpha \in C^p (X ;\, R)$ and $\beta \in C^q(X ;\, R)$ we define

$
\alpha \smile \beta = \Delta^* h(\alpha \otimes \beta)
$.

As $\Delta^*$ and $h$ are chain maps, $\smile$ induces a well defined
product on cohomology groups, known as the cup product. Hence the direct
sum of the cohomology groups of $X$ has the structure of a ring. This is
called the cohomology ring of $X$.
